competencies.name: Operative ensures they have been trained to operate the vehicle tail lifting equipment
competencies.supportingText: 1. What is the correct training for waste collection operations using tail lifting equipment?

competencies.name: Operative follows manufacturer’s instructions for operating the tail‑lift equipment
Operative always uses load restraint flaps and fall prevention systems where fitted
Operative avoids placing feet in the way of the descending tail-lift
Operative avoids putting hands where they might be trapped by a moving tail-lift
Operative ensures all items are safely stowed and secured before driving off
Operative checks that first aid box and eye wash are present and complete
competencies.supportingText: 1. What first aid equipment should be carried in the vehicle?

competencies.name: Operative only collects waste from a suitable location outside householder’s premises
Operative inspects appliance inside and out and removes any items that may drop off in transit
Operative ensures that pipe work and compressor units in refrigerators and freezers are not damaged when handling them
Operative informs supervisor if there is significant infestation in the waste
competencies.supportingText:
1. What are the common forms of infestation in gas and electrical appliances?
  2. What action should be taken if infestation is found?

competencies.name: Operative takes care to note kerbs, steps, potholes, uneven paving and other trip hazards
Operative keeps ground in vision as far as is practicable and conducts checks where vision is lost before proceeding
Operative takes extra care in wet and icy conditions
competencies.supportingText: 1. What action should be taken to avoid or control adverse effects of wet or icy ground /floor conditions underfoot?

competencies.name: Operative always wears protective footwear issued by the company
Operative tests the weight of item before lifting and only lifts items within own capability
Operative asks for assistance if load is heavy or awkward
competencies.supportingText: 1. Which types of load could require assistance when moving?

competencies.name: Operative gets a firm grip on the load before lifting and ensures a firm footing
Operative lifts with one foot in front of the other and with knees bent using leg muscles to achieve the lift
Operative exercises care when moving loads which restrict sight of the ground, steps or obstructions in front
Operative exercises care when manually handling items in wet and icy conditions
competencies.supportingText: 1. What action should be taken to avoid or control adverse effects of wet or icy ground /floor conditions underfoot?

competencies.name: Operative turns by moving the feet rather than twisting at the waist when carrying a load
Operative uses handling aids as required including slings and sack-trucks
competencies.supportingText: 1. What are the common handling aids available to you?

competencies.name: Operative avoids jamming hands between door frames when moving awkward items of furniture
Operative removes drawers on items of furniture or secures them prior to removal
Operative  segregates items following disposal site regulations when safe to do so
competencies.supportingText:
1. What are the usual disposal site regulations regarding the segregation of waste?
  2. When is it unsafe to segregate waste at a disposal site?

competencies.name: Operative reports to supervisor when requests to segregate items will involve difficult manual handling, where there is poor access or where unsecured loads have to be moved around a site
